author: sproul
content:
While debugging some other stuff I noticed that Geth returns `withdrawals: null` for `eth_getBlockByHash` for post-Capella blocks without any withdrawals. IMO this should be `withdrawals: []`

e.g. 

```
curl -s http://localhost:5052/eth/v1/beacon/blocks/6104 | jq
{
  "code": 500,
  "message": "UNHANDLED_ERROR: ExecutionLayerErrorPayloadReconstruction(0x18ac69a3e9e997635db31e0b89986bd6936718679dcb64b598fa3aaa5cc1354a, EngineError(Api { error: Json(Error(\"invalid type: null, expected a sequence\", line: 0, column: 0)) }))",
  "stacktraces": []
}
```

(on Lighthouse-Geth)

author: m.kalinin
content:
A few Engine API cleanups that I think makes sense to be a part of Shanghai, https://github.com/ethereum/execution-apis/pull/338

It would be great if client devs can take a look and say if there is any unexpected complexity in replacing `INVALID_BLOCK_HASH` with `INVALID`, the other two looks like a no brainer.

content: Deprecates `exchangeTransitionConfiguration` and proposes two ways of removing this method from Mainnet compliant clients, https://github.com/ethereum/execution-apis/pull/339

author: parithosh
content:
So atleast according to the poll, we're gonna hold off on a big public testnet. It'll be a larger scale devnet instead, with some external permissioned participants. We'll try and get configs out today and genesis late tomorrow.

It'll have the following features: 
    Timestamp based forking
    Withdrawals
    Warm COINBASE
    PUSH0
    Limit/meter initcode (Should we remove this <@360491619402776577> ?)

CL: spec v1.3.0-alpha.2
EL: eip-4895 @ commit 0fa80ec
EngineAPI version? - TBD
PR 314: getPayloadV2 in blockValue format : Yes, with 0 as a stub as a bare minimum.
PR 146(add getPayloadBodies method) & PR 218(getPayloadBodiesByRangeV1) NOT required
Genesis.json of EL has shanghaiTime as the field name

author: jgm
content: Yes.

author: jgm
content: Note that `ethdo` as of version 1.27.0-rc2 supports the changed REST API so sends an array rather than individual change operations.

author: jgm
content: (To expand on my previous rather terse answer: if a mnemonic is provided alone then `ethdo` will scan the derived addresses to see if they are present in the list of validators.  It will scan 1000 validators past the last validator it finds in the list, so if there was a validator at index 900 then it will end up scanning to 1900 before stopping.  if someone has done something non-standard enough to be beyond that they can enter the individual validators themselves with mnemonic and path.)

author: potuz
content: ahh ok, so my example was off just by 1000 üôÇ

author: jgm
content: Yeah I figure that if you are mucking around with indices to that extent you know what you are doing enough to them specify it manually.  The easy path is designed for those who used the launchpad/deposit CLI in a relatively standard way.

author: sauliusgrigaitis
content: Asking here as was changed for version v1.3.0-alpha.2 -  https://media.githubusercontent.com/media/ethereum/consensus-spec-tests/v1.3.0-alpha.2/tests/mainnet/bellatrix/sync/optimistic/pyspec_tests/from_syncing_to_invalid/steps.yaml . So the scenario is about three payloads that first got `VALID`, then somehow became `SYNCING` with `latest_valid_hash: null`. My understanding was that once the payload is `VALID` it should not become `SYNCING`. Do I miss something?

author: sauliusgrigaitis
content: Or is it better to fill a ticket in the `consensus-spec-tests` repo?

author: hsiaowei
content: The `VALID` payloads and the `SYCING` payloads are two different forks. More details on https://github.com/ethereum/consensus-specs/pull/2982

author: hsiaowei
content: `consensus-spec-tests` are generated by `consensus-specs`. If it's about one specific test case, I would say you can fill a ticket in `consensus-specs` repo. üôÇ

author: sauliusgrigaitis
content: well, I still miss something. So the previous test version https://media.githubusercontent.com/media/ethereum/consensus-spec-tests/v1.2.0/tests/mainnet/bellatrix/sync/optimistic/pyspec_tests/from_syncing_to_invalid/steps.yaml had different `block_hashes` on the different branches. So it was perfectly fine that one branch was `VALID` and the other one was `SYNCING`. However, in the new v1.3.0-alpha.2 `block_hashes` are the same in both `VALID` and `SYNCING` branches. My understanding was that EL can't return such a thing. What do I miss?

author: hsiaowei
content: Aaah I see your point now. We should revert the recent https://github.com/ethereum/consensus-specs/pull/3126/files change of this test case so that the two payloads will be distinct. üëç

author: sauliusgrigaitis
content: should I open ticket so this will not get lost?

author: hsiaowei
content: Yes please! üëç

author: potuz
content: cc <@363800010518822915> we don't catch this since our mock completely disregards the hash, we just do whatever the testvector says. I think we're safe without any change, but tagging you here for visibility only because Grandine seems to have caught this

author: sauliusgrigaitis
content: Done https://github.com/ethereum/consensus-specs/issues/3172 . Thanks for quick response!

author: sauliusgrigaitis
content: yea, was a bit surprised it was not caught previously because Grandine is probably the last client implementing this spec.

author: potuz
content: we just don't care about the blockhash since the mock does whatever the testvector itself says it should do, I'm guessing every client but Grandine implemented this that way

author: sauliusgrigaitis
content: yea, but for this test you should track payload statuses and the interesting thing that this test changes the payload status from `VALID` to `SYNCING`. Do you track these statuses without connection to the payload hash?

author: potuz
content: Hmm, prysm ignores changes VALID -> SYNCING if I remember correctly

author: parithosh
content:
The genesis configs for `withdrawal-devnet-1` are now out: https://github.com/ethpandaops/withdrawals-testnet/blob/master/withdrawal-devnet-1/custom_config_data

Genesis is tomorrow (22nd dec) @  12PM CEST, Capella is at epoch 40 (~4PM CEST). We do have some extra validator keys available if any client team wants to take part. This won't be a fully public testnet, it'll be semi-public, some external entities will be running validators to test features. Depending on the stability of this network, we'll announce another fully public network soon üòÑ 

Tooling links can be found here: https://withdrawalsdevnet1.ethpandaops.io/

author: marioevz
content:
Hi all, I have been working on a hive-interop test suite for withdrawals and wanted to share the current work in progress and how to run the simulator over here:
https://notes.ethereum.org/@marioevz/hive-withdrawals-interop

Bad news is that most client combinations seem to be failing most of tests, so further debugging is required from my side, but please feel free to take a look, run the simulators, suggest more test cases, or suggest any changes you deem necessary.
